ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: research ethics
Epidemiological analysis and study designs.
Ethics
Have a board view of the research ethics and know some issues should be wared in advance.
Ethics.
Academic ethics and integrity.
I learn basic knowledge about epidemiology.
The basic idea of how research ethics in public health area would be.
I warned about ethics.
Research ethics
understanding the basis behind research ethics and restrictions

I have understood the concepts in scientific research, including scientific misconduct, data acquisition and management, responsibilities of mentor and mentee, publication and authorship, and conflict of interest. I have also learned how to protect the privacy and confidentiality of human subjects in scientific research.
How to approach mentor-mentee relationships. Also learned about plagiarism and conducting ethical research.
I came to realize how truly grey many situations in academia can be - and that we must simply strive to do our best with the best available information, science, evidence, and ethics we have.
Research ethics

I found this course very useful in better understanding the university expectations regarding professional comportment. I appreciated the opportunity to interact with Dr. Tschudi on a more individual level and to get to know him and the other resources available to us at YSPH.
Basic principles of epi

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: fun and casual environment to talk about some current issues in research ethics. maybe could have condensed the material/covered more topics.
Content was a bit heavy. Too many exams.
strength: very interactive
The experience shared by the instructor is really impressive.
talks about lots of real-life issues. Very vivid.

The course provides important topics that we must learn about academic ethics. It was well organized with clear definitions helpful case studies and discussions. The course was mandatory for graduate students. I took the same course before as a Master student. I understand that it is important to remind students the importance of ethics issues and to refresh related knowledge. However, the material did change much. So it was a little boring taking the curse again.
It is organized well.
strengths: the slides are clear and informative weaknesses: it would be better if the professor could be more animated
it is a concise summary of research ethics
This course provides a wide range of knowledge about key concepts in scientific research, but the engagement of the students is not very high.
Having the sessions over lunch rather than at the end of the day.

Strengths of the class were the openness on the part of Prof. Tschudi (and guest lecturers) about the peaks and valleys of academia as well as the engagement of student opinions, perspectives, and experiences with the topics (via questions, case studies, etc.). The only big weakness is the lack of engagement on the part of ~1/2 of the students (they and you know who they are...).

I thought the course was strong given its important content and could have been stronger if the extra sessions facilitated by Kate Nyhan were included as part of the course and not just an add-on. Sessions from OCS, CTL, and other YSPH resources would have fit nicely into the course to make it more practical.
Less busy homework. More group sessions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: required class but enjoyed the professor and having time to see other new students in the program.
Maybe
Get to be familiar with ethic knowledge before start research.
Knowing ethics is really important.
I would recommend this course to first year students, because ethics issues are important.
Yes
I recommend this course because it is compulsory for our program.
Yes
It is compulsory
sure! it provides a good basis for research ethics and the reasons behind the restrictions in place
Yes, I recommend this course to other students, especially those who have just come in contact with scientific research.
This is a required course so doesn't apply.
Yes - besides it being a requirement, it's good to refresh and discuss these issues!
The course is required, but I would recommend it to all students, especially as one of the few opportunities to meet with all students in the MS/PhD cohort.
Less busy work homework and more applied studies
